Award.AwardTitle: SOLAR Collaborative: Photonic Enhancement of Organic Photovoltaics to Enable Higher Efficiencies and Exotic Mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project brings together faculty and scientists at the University of Denver and the University of Colorado at Boulder to study new materials and concepts in organic photovoltaics (OPV). It combines new mathematical methods to describe photonic processes with novel plasmonic nanostructures for enhancing optical absorption and new organic semiconductors for control of exciton flow and charge carrier dynamics. The theoretical foundations of linear and nonlinear processes in surface plasmons and their interactions with organic chromophores are explored, and the interplay between surface plasmons and FÃ¶rster Resonant Energy Transfer (FRET) is investigated. New organic molecules are synthesized that incorporate graphenic and other moieties with exceptional charge transport and excited-state properties along with liquid-crystalline functionality for improved molecular ordering. The overall goal is to enhance the density of excitons created in OPV devices to enable higher efficiencies as well as coherent control of excited state dynamics and multiexciton phenomena. The work entails significant collaborations with the National Renewable Energy Laboratory and the University of Toronto.

This project aims to advance the fundamental knowledge of OPV materials and mechanisms and to provide impetus for moving OPV to the broader market as a low-cost solar energy technology that can be produced on a truly large scale. The interdisciplinary nature of the project gives graduate students and postdoctoral trainees exposure to a variety of research settings and fosters their learning and career growth. The project generates educational materials that are broadly disseminated through websites and through the National Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Education Digital Library (NSDL). Outreach activities for local high school science teachers in the Denver and Boulder areas enable hands-on experience with intensive workshops on solar energy and nanotechnology. Demonstrations, exhibits, and instructional materials are provided to Colorado institutions such as the Wings Over the Rockies Air & Space Museum and the Mamie Dowd Eisenhower Library.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research has significantly enhanced the understanding of wave propagation and dynamics in 2-dimensional structure termed Photonic Graphene and nonlinear wave propagation along dielectric/metal interfaces. Photonic Graphene is a honeycomb lattice pattern created in a nonlinear photorefractive crystal. By investigating wave propagation in this structure both theoretically and experimentally, we demonstrated a peculiar wave propagation phenomenon called vortex formation. This was the first experimental demonstration of a quantity called pseudospin. Since pseudospin is a key to many novel phenomena such as quantum Hall effect, we envisage our results will have broader impact to other branches of physics and material sciences. In addition, our work also brings about a new mechanism to generate optical vortices which may find applications in photonics. 

We have demonstrated photon upconversion by cooperative energy pooling (CEP) in a thin film material for the first time, utilizing molecular mixtures of organic chromophores selected for photophysical properties that enable the CEP process. Furthermore, we studied new molecular designs that could promote the CEP process. In principle, it should be possible to take advantage of the longer-lived (> 1ns) S2 state of the azulene molecule in a fashion whereby it can be used to promote light absorption and charge generation, when embedded in a suitable electron (or hole) accepting host. The use of singlet states in the CEP process provides for ultrafast upconversion that can, in principle, be nearly lossless in energy and thus dramatically improve the performance of many photonic devices including photovoltaic devices.

We have established theoretical framework to describe the plasmon enhancement of frequency upconversion process. We identified the enhancement mechanisms for the three processes involved in upconversion – absorption, energy transfer and emission – and showed how surface plasmon impact these processes. We have also demonstrated plasmon enhancement of upconversion experimentally. Particularly, we demonstrated that the surface plasmon can enhance the energy transfer energy transfer process. There has been an on-going debate on whether surface plasmon can actually enhance energy transfer rate. Our study shows direct experimental evidence that energy transfer rate is actually enhanced by surface plasmon.

Taken together, this project showed how cooperative processes can be controlled and used for energy technology. Efficient energy pooling and upconversion could lead to breaking the fundamental efficiency limit of solar cells, broadly impacting our society which depends increasingly on energy technology. Efficient photonic upconversion also has application in other fields such as biomedical imaging and cancer therapy, and optical computing applications. Furthermore, linear and nonlinear wave phenomena we studied are centrally important to many fields including optics, electromagnetics, fluid dynamics, plasma physics, Bose-Einstein Condensation etc. and will broadly impact the scientific communities.
